September 23, 2007: Fiction
A THOUSAND SPLENDID SUNS, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead, $25.95.) A
friendship between two women in Afghanistan against the backdrop of 30 years of
war.
THE WHEEL OF DARKNESS, by Douglas Preston and Lincoln Child. (Warner,
$25.99.) A Tibetan abbot asks the F.B.I. agent Aloysius Pendergast to help recover
a stolen relic with evil powers.
BONES TO ASHES, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $25.95.) The forensic
anthropologist Temperance Brennan is asked to examine the skeleton of a young
girl in Canada, where, many years ago, her best friend disappeared.
DARK POSSESSION, by Christine Feehan. (Berkley, $24.95.) A Seattle counselor
for battered women is wooed by a shape-shifter in Brazil; the 18th Carpathian novel.
THE ELVES OF CINTRA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $26.95.) The
second volume of the Genesis of Shannara series is set in postapocalyptic Seattle.
TREE OF SMOKE, by Denis Johnson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) The Vietnam
War in the experience of military intelligence officers.
PLAY DIRTY, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $26.95.) A disgraced N.F.L.
quarterback struggles to remake his life.
HEARTSICK, by Chelsea Cain. (St. Martin’s Minotaur, $23.95.) A detective
obsesses over the beautiful, sadistic serial killer who nearly tortured him to death.
THE QUICKIE, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
A police officer’s attempt to get back at her husband goes dangerously awry.
SONGS WITHOUT WORDS, by Ann Packer. (Knopf, $24.95.) The relationship
between two old friends is shaken when the daughter of one of them attempts
suicide.
AWAY, by Amy Bloom. (Random House, $23.95.) An immigrant who escaped a
Russian pogrom crosses America.
SWEET REVENGE, by Diane Mott Davidson. (Morrow, $25.95.) A former district
attorney is found dead in a library, and the caterer Goldy Schulz thinks she knows
the killer.
LORD JOHN AND THE BROTHERHOOD OF THE BLADE, by Diana Gabaldon.
(Delacorte, $25.) Lord John Grey is haunted by his father’s murder 17 years earlier.
LOVING FRANK, by Nancy Horan. (Ballantine, $23.95.) A historical novel about the
scandalous affair between a married Chicago woman and the architect Frank Lloyd
Wright.
September 23, 2007
Non-Fiction
GIVING, by Bill Clinton. (Knopf, $24.95.) The former president describes people
and projects that save lives and solve problems around the world.
MOTHER TERESA: COME BE MY LIGHT. (Doubleday, $22.95.) Writings and
reflections on her spiritual journey.
LONE SURVIVOR, by Marcus Luttrell with Patrick Robinson. (Little, Brown,
$24.99.) The only survivor of a Navy Seal operation in northern Afghanistan
describes the battle, his comrades and his courageous escape.
DEAD CERTAIN, by Robert Draper. (Free Press, $28.) A portrait of George W.
Bush as a willful optimist who prizes familiarity and dislikes criticism and bad
news.
QUIET STRENGTH, by Tony Dungy with Nathan Whitaker. (Tyndale, $26.99.) A
memoir by the first black coach to win a Super Bowl (with the Indianpolis Colts in
WONDERFUL TONIGHT, by Pattie Boyd with Penny Junor. (Harmony, $25.95.) A
rock muse (she inspired the songs “Something” and “Layla”) recalls falling in love
with Eric Clapton while she was married to George Harrison.
THE WORLD WITHOUT US, by Alan Weisman. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s,
$24.95.) What Earth would be like if humans disappeared.
THINGS I OVERHEARD WHILE TALKING TO MYSELF, by Alan Alda. (Random
House, $24.95.) The actor describes his search for meaning in life following a
nearfatal illness.
IT’S ALL ABOUT HIM, by Denise Jackson with Ellen Vaughn. (Thomas Nelson,
$24.99.) The wife of the country music star Alan Jackson describes how religious
faith restored her marriage.
BLONDE AMBITION, by Rita Cosby. (Grand Central, $23.99.) The life and death
of Anna Nicole Smith.
GOD IS NOT GREAT, by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $24.99.) Religion as a
malignant force in the world.
THE ISRAEL LOBBY AND U.S. FOREIGN POLICY, by John J. Mearsheimer and
Stephen M. Walt. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Two scholars argue that the
Israel lobby has distorted American foreign policy in a way that puts our security at
risk.
YOU CAN RUN BUT YOU CAN’T HIDE, by Duane Chapman with Laura Morton.
(Hyperion, $25.95.) A memoir by the star of A & E’s “Dog the Bounty Hunter.”
